react.text: What is the purpose of React?

options.text: Manage and render web and native UI

react.answer: Manage and render web and native UI
react.explanation:
React is a free and open-source library for web and native user interfaces (UI). 
React lets to build user interfaces out of individual pieces called components. 
React components receive data and return what should appear on the screen. 
You can pass them new data in response to an interaction, like when the user types into an input. 
React will then update the screen to match the new data.

react.text: What does JSX stand for?
react.answer: JavaScript XML
react.explanation:
JSX (JavaScript XML, formally JavaScript Syntax eXtension) is an XML-like extension to the JavaScript language syntax. 
Initially created by Facebook for use with React, JSX has been adopted by multiple web frameworks

react.text: How do you pass data to a component in React?
react.answer: Using props
react.explanation:
React components use props to communicate with each other. 
Every parent component can pass some information to its child components by giving them props. 
Props might remind you of HTML attributes, but you can pass any JavaScript value through them, including objects, arrays, and functions. 
The props you can pass to an <img> tag are predefined (ReactDOM conforms to the HTML standard). 
But you can pass any props to your own components, such as <Avatar>, to customize them.

react.text: What Hooks means in React?
react.answer:
Hooks are special functions that are only available while React is Rendering. 
Hooks‚Äîfunctions starting with use‚Äîcan only be called at the top level of your components or your own Hooks. 
You can‚Äôt call Hooks inside conditions, loops, or other nested functions. 
Hooks are functions, but it‚Äôs helpful to think of them as unconditional declarations about your component‚Äôs needs. 
You ‚Äúuse‚Äù React features at the top of your component similar to how you ‚Äúimport‚Äù modules at the top of your file.
react.explanation:
Hooks are special functions that are only available while React is Rendering. 
Hooks‚Äîfunctions starting with use‚Äîcan only be called at the top level of your components or your own Hooks. 
You can‚Äôt call Hooks inside conditions, loops, or other nested functions. Hooks are functions, but it‚Äôs helpful to think of them as unconditional declarations about your component‚Äôs needs. 
You ‚Äúuse‚Äù React features at the top of your component similar to how you ‚Äúimport‚Äù modules at the top of your file.

react.text: What is a state in React? (Name things for which it is responsible for)
react.answer: Internal object to a component
react.explanation:
UseState Hook provides 2 things: 1) State variable retain the data between renders. 
2) State setter function updates the variable and trigger React to render the component again. 
Because while changing some data like it is common in JS (let x....) - React doesn‚Äôt realize it needs to render the component again with the new data. 
When React renders this component a second time, it renders it from scratch‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt consider any changes to the local variables

react.text: Can React be used without a framework?

options.text: Yes. Because React is already a framework
No. Because React is a library
No. Because every app needs a framework
Yes. But developers recommend using frameworks

react.answer: Yes. But developers recommend using frameworks if you need routing, data fetching at first, etc.
react.explanation:
Even if you don‚Äôt need routing or data fetching at first, you‚Äôll likely want to add some libraries for them. 
As your JavaScript bundle grows with every new feature, you might have to figure out how to split code for every route individually. 
As your audience includes more users with poor network conditions and low-end devices, you might need to generate HTML from your components to display content early‚Äîeither on the server, or during the build time. 
Changing your setup to run some of your code on the server or during the build can be very tricky. These problems are not React-specific. 
This is why Svelte has SvelteKit, Vue has Nuxt, and so on. To solve these problems on your own, you‚Äôll need to integrate your bundler with your router and with your data fetching library.

react.text: Which hook lets you keep your component synchronized with external systems?
react.answer: useEffect
react.explanation:
An Effect lets you keep your component synchronized with some external system (like a chat service). 
Here, external system means any piece of code that‚Äôs not controlled by React, such as: 
1) A timer managed with setInterval() and clearInterval(). 
2) An event subscription using window.addEventListener() and window.removeEventListener(). 
3) A third-party animation library with an API like animation.start() and animation.reset().

react.text: What does React use under the hood to manage the DOM efficiently?
react.answer: Virtual DOM
react.explanation:
Virtual DOM functions as an efficient alternative for updating the DOM in response to changes, significantly reducing the time required. 
Therefore, React uses Virtual DOM. It involves updating the JavaScript object directly.
It can produce 20000 virtual dom nodes in a second and created completely from scratch on every setState and dispatch.

react.text: What is Reconciliation process?
react.answer:
The process of generating a new virtual DOM tree and comparing the old and the new virtual DOM trees 
to register all the changes that need to be done to the real DOM.
react.explanation:
After every component update, React creates a new virtual DOM tree. 
It then compares the old tree with the new tree to register all the changes that need to be done to the real DOM. 
This process of generating a new tree and comparing is called reconciliation. 
React uses a diffing algorithm in reconciliation process to compare both trees to effectively update the UI in a minimum number of operations.

react.text: What is the use of the useReducer hook in React?

options.text: No longer in use in v18 React and > vers.
To fetch data and reduce it in a component

react.answer: Manage state in complex scenarios: takes a reducer function and an initial state
react.explanation: useReducer is usually preferable to useState when you have complex state logic that involves multiple sub-values or when the next state depends on the previous one.

react.text: What are the key features of ReactJS?
react.answer:
1) component-based architecture, 
2)performance optimization by minimizing direct DOM manipulation (virtual DOM implementation) 
3) code reusability through reusable components 
4)declarative syntax 
5) JSX for easier UI development
react.explanation:
The key features of ReactJS are its component-based architecture, virtual DOM implementation for efficient rendering, 
code reusability through reusable components, declarative syntax and JSX for easier UI development, 
unidirectional data flow for predictable updates, and performance optimization by minimizing direct DOM manipulation.

react.text: How do you import React in a file?
react.answer: import React from ‚Äùreact‚Äù

react.text: Which hook is used to update the user interface before a background operation, like a network request, completes?
react.answer: useOptimistic
react.explanation:
useOptimistic is a Hook that allows you to update the user interface before a background operation, like a network request, completes. 
This can improve the perceived performance of your application by making it feel more responsive. 
In the context of forms, this technique helps to make apps feel more responsive. When a user submits a form, instead of waiting for the server‚Äôs response to reflect the changes, the interface is immediately updated with the expected outcome.

react.text: Which hook is used to handle state in a functional component?
react.answer: useState
react.explanation: useState is a Hook that allows you to retain data between renders and a function to update this data.

react.text: What is the use of keys in React?

options.text: To group multiple elements in an array
To create an array of components
To identify unique elements in array

react.answer: To identify unique elements in an array of components or elements that are rendered dynamically
react.explanation:
Keys tell React which array item each component corresponds to, so that it can match them up later. 
This becomes important if your array items can move (e.g. due to sorting), get inserted, or get deleted. 
A well-chosen key helps React infer what exactly has happened, and make the correct updates to the DOM tree. 
Rather than generating keys on the fly, you should include them in your data

react.text: Which frameworks support all the features you need to deploy and scale your React app in production and are working towards supporting our full-stack architecture vision?
react.answer: Remix / Next.js / Gatsby / Expo
react.explanation:
1)Remix is a full-stack React framework with nested routing. 
It lets you break your app into nested parts that can load data in parallel and refresh in response to the user actions. 
2) Next.js‚Äô Pages Router is a full-stack React framework. 
It‚Äôs versatile and lets you create React apps of any size‚Äîfrom a mostly static blog to a complex dynamic application. 
3)Gatsby is a React framework for fast CMS-backed websites. 
Its rich plugin ecosystem and its GraphQL data layer simplify integrating content, APIs, and services into one website. 
4)Expo (for native apps) is a React framework that lets you create universal Android, iOS, and web apps with truly native UIs. 
It provides an SDK for React Native that makes the native parts easier to use.

react.text: What is the difference between React and other JavaScript frameworks/libraries?
react.answer:
1) ReactJS focuses solely on the view layer, allowing developers to integrate it easily with other libraries or frameworks. 
2)React also introduces the concept of a virtual DOM, which enhances performance by minimizing direct manipulation of the actual DOM.
react.explanation:
ReactJS differs from other JavaScript frameworks/libraries in several ways. 
It focuses solely on the view layer, allowing developers to integrate it easily with other libraries or frameworks. 
React also introduces the concept of a virtual DOM, which enhances performance by minimizing direct manipulation of the actual DOM.

react.text: What is the difference between props and state?
react.answer:
Props (short for properties) and state are both used in ReactJS to manage data, but they serve different purposes. 
Props are used to pass data from a parent component to a child component, while state is used to manage and update data within a component itself.
react.explanation:
React components use props to communicate with each other. 
Every parent component can pass some information to its child components by giving them props. 
Props might remind you of HTML attributes, but you can pass any JavaScript value through them, including objects, arrays, and functions. 
Props let you think about parent and child components independently.

react.text: What are the components in React?
react.answer: Components are the building blocks of a React application, allowing developers to create reusable and modular pieces of UI.
react.explanation:
Components are one of the core concepts of React. 
They are the foundation upon which developer build user interfaces(UI). 
React supports all of the browser built-in HTML and SVG components. 
All of the built-in browser components support some props and events. 
You can create a custom HTML elements

react.text: How to share one state between two different components?
react.answer: By lifting state up
react.explanation:
Lifting state up is a technique in React for sharing state between two different components. 
To lift state up, remove state from both of components, move it to their closest common parent, and then pass it down to them via props.  
This is known as lifting state up, and it‚Äôs one of the most common things developers do writing React code

react.text: What is a controlled component in React?

options.text: A component that controls its own state
A component that controlled by parent

react.answer: A component that controlled by parent
react.explanation:
It is common to call a component with some local state ‚Äúuncontrolled‚Äù. 
In contrast, you might say a component is ‚Äúcontrolled‚Äù when the important information in it is driven by props rather than its own local state. 
This lets the parent component fully specify its behavior. 
Uncontrolled components are easier to use within their parents because they require less configuration. 
But they‚Äôre less flexible when you want to coordinate them together. 
Controlled components are maximally flexible, but they require the parent components to fully configure them with props.

react.text: What are the differences between useRef and useState?
react.answer:
1) useRef is `mutable`, while useState - `immmutable`. 
2)useRef doesn`t trigger re-renders | useState triggers re-renders
react.explanation:
1) useRef is `mutable` = you can modify and update current‚Äôs value, 
while useState - `immmutable` = you must use the state setting function to modify state. 
2) useRef does not trigger re-renders when its value changes, 
while useState triggers re-renders when its value changes.

react.text: Explain the concept of React Hooks and their benefits
react.answer:
Benefits: 
1) Simplify the logic and structure of components 
2) Reduce the need for class components 
3) Improve code reusability and maintainability 
4) Enhance performance and optimization
react.explanation:
React Hooks (introduced in React 16.8) are defined using JavaScript functions, but they represent a special type of reusable UI logic with restrictions on where they can be called. 
Benefits: 
1) Simplify the logic and structure of components 
2) Reduce the need for class components 
3) Improve code reusability and maintainability 
4) Enhance performance and optimization

react.text: Can web browsers read JSX directly?
react.answer:
No. Web browsers cannot read JSX directly. 
This is because they are built to only read regular JS objects and JSX is not a regular JavaScript object.
react.explanation:
JSX is not a regular JavaScript object. 
JSX and JS are not the same, although they share some similarities. Here are the key differences: 
1)Usage: JSX is primarily used in React applications for defining the structure and behavior of UI components. 
It is the preferred way to write components in React. 
JS, on the other hand, can be used for various purposes in JavaScript development, such as defining functions, variables, and logic. 
2)Transformation: JSX code needs to be transformed into regular JavaScript code before it can be executed by the browser or JavaScript engine. 
For this transformation you‚Äôll need a transpiler. 
JS code, on the other hand, can be executed directly by the browser or JavaScript engine without any transformation. 
**While JSX is the commonly used syntax for writing React components, it is possible to write React components using pure JavaScript without JSX.**

react.text: Explain how the event propagation works
react.answer:
Event handlers catch events from any children your component might have. 
Event ‚Äúbubbles‚Äù or ‚Äúpropagates‚Äù up ↑ the tree: it starts with where the event happened, and then goes up the tree
react.explanation:
For example: <div> contains two buttons, and both: the <div> and each button have their own onClick handlers. 
If you click on either button, its onClick will run first, followed by the parent <div>‚Äùs onClick 
**All events propagate in React except `onScroll`, which only works on the JSX tag you attach it to.**

react.text: What is the difference between e.stopPropagation() and e.preventDefault()?
react.answer: e.stopPropagation() stops the event from bubbling up the DOM tree, while e.preventDefault() prevents the default browser behavior for the few events that have it.
react.explanation:
For preventing an event from reaching parent components `e.stopPropagation()` should be called. 
 `e.stopPropagation()`, preventing the event from bubbling further. 
 Some browser events have default behavior associated with them. 
For example, a <form> submit event, which happens when a button inside of it is clicked, will reload the whole page by default. 
To stop this from happening `e.preventDefault()` should be called.

react.text: How to add an event handler in React?
react.answer: onClick={handleClick}
react.explanation:
onClick={handleClick} = tells React to remember function handleClick and only call it when the user clicks to the element. 
 onClick={handleClick()} - is wrong, because it calls handleClick immediately, during rendering, without any clicks from the user. 
Second way to add the event handler is by passing inline code directly to the element: onClick={() => alert(‚Äô‚Äô...‚Äô‚Äô)}> passes the () => alert(‚Äô‚Äô...‚Äô‚Äô) function

react.text: What is the purpose of useTransition?
react.answer: useTransition is a React Hook that allows to update the state without blocking the UI.
react.explanation:
Transitions allow to keep user interface responsive even on slow devices or in the middle of a re-render. 
For example, if the user clicks a tab but then change their mind and click another tab, they can do that without waiting for the first re-render to finish. 
Without useTransition in such case - the app freezes while rendering and the UI becomes unresponsive

react.text: How is deferring useDeferredValue from debouncing and throttling?
react.answer:
useDeferredValue shows stale content while fresh content is loading, but unlike debouncing or throttling, it: 
1)Doesn‚Äôt require choosing any fixed delay. 
2)Is interruptible by default.
react.explanation:
Debouncing means app will wait for the user to stop typing (e.g. for a second) before updating the list. 
Throttling means updating the list every once in a while (e.g. at most once a second). 
While these techniques are helpful in some cases, useDeferredValue is better suited to optimizing rendering, because it is deeply integrated with React itself and adapts to the user‚Äôs device: 
1)nIf the user‚Äôs device is fast (e.g. powerful laptop), the deferred re-render would happen almost immediately and wouldn‚Äôt be noticeable. 
If the user‚Äôs device is slow, the list would ‚Äúlag behind‚Äù the input proportionally to how slow the device is. 
2)useDeferredValue is interruptible by default. This means that if React is in the middle of re-rendering a large list, but the user makes another keystroke, 
React will abandon that re-render, handle the keystroke, and then start rendering in the background again. 
By contrast, debouncing and throttling still produce a janky experience because they‚Äôre blocking: they merely postpone the moment when rendering blocks the keystroke.

react.text: What are event handlers in React and how to use them?
react.answer:
React lets developers to add event handlers to JSX code. 
Event handlers are custom functions that will be triggered in response to interactions like clicking, hovering, focusing form inputs, and so on. 
To add an event handler - define a function and then pass it as a prop to the appropriate JSX tag. 
Or pass inline code directly to the element.
react.explanation:
For example: function handleClick() {alert(...)} ... <button onClick={handleClick}>Click me</button>  
 or inline: <button onClick={() => alert(‚Äô‚Äô...‚Äô‚Äô)}>Click me</button>

react.text: What is the correct way to lift state up in React?

options.text: Moving the state to a child component
Moving the state to a common ancestor

react.answer: Moving the state to a common ancestor component
react.explanation: Remove state from the component, move it to its closest ancestor, and then pass it down via props

react.text: What are portals in React? When would you use them?
react.answer: Portal lets you render some children into a different part of the DOM.
react.explanation:
Portals in React provide a way to render children components into a different DOM node, outside the current component‚Äùs DOM hierarchy. 
They allow you to render components at a different location in the DOM, which is useful for scenarios like modals, popovers, or tooltips, 
where the component needs to be positioned relative to a specific DOM element outside its parent. 
A portal only changes the physical placement of the DOM node. 
In every other way, the JSX that renders in a portal acts as a child node of the React component that renders it. 
For example, the child can access the context provided by the parent tree, and events bubble up from children to parents according to the React tree.

react.text: How can you create a functional component in React?
react.answer: export default function Greeting() {...}
react.explanation:
Component could be created by defining a function that returns JSX. 
Class components (class Greeting extends Component {....}) are still supported by React, but it is not recommended to use them in a new code.

react.text: What is the purpose of the useLayoutEffect hook in React?

options.text: To manage state in a functional component
Handle side effects in functional component

react.answer: To update the UI synchronously before the browser paints
react.explanation:
Most components don‚Äôt need to know their position and size on the screen to decide what to render. They only return some JSX. 
Then the browser calculates their layout (position and size) and repaints the screen. 
React guarantees that the code inside useLayoutEffect and any state updates scheduled inside it will be processed before the browser repaints the screen. 
This lets to render the element, measure it, and re-render it again without the user noticing the first extra render. 
In other words, useLayoutEffect blocks the browser from painting. 
**useLayoutEffect can hurt performance (because it blocks the browser from painting), so it is better to use useEffect in every possible case**

react.text: What is the purpose of the useCallback hook in React?

options.text: Manage state in a functional component
Handle side effects in functional component

react.answer: Memoize functions & prevent unnecessary re-renders
react.explanation:
useCallback(fn, dependencies) - On the initial render, useCallback returns the function that has been passed. 
During subsequent renders, it will either return an already stored function from the last render (if the dependencies haven‚Äôt changed), 
or return the function that has been passed during this render. 
In other words, useCallback caches a function between re-renders until its dependencies change. 
**Note that useCallback does not prevent creating the function: there ia always a creation of a function (and that‚Äôs fine!), 
but React ignores it and gives a cached function if nothing changed in dependencies.**

react.text: How is useCallback related to useMemo?
react.answer:
They both are useful for preventing unnecessary re-renders and avoiding unnecessary calculations. They both cache some data, the difference is in what they‚Äôre letting to cache:. 
useMemo caches the result of calling some function. useCallback caches the function itself.
react.explanation:
By default, when a component re-renders, React re-renders all of its children recursively. 
This is fine for components that don‚Äôt require much calculation to re-render, but in other cases it is better to optimize code. 
useMemo & useCallback are both useful during optimization of a child component. 
They let to memoize (or, in other words, cache) something that is passing down. 
The difference is in what they‚Äôre letting to cache: 
useMemo caches the result of calling some function. useCallback caches the function itself.

react.text: Why React uses className over class attribute?
react.answer:
React uses className instead of class in HTML because class is a reserved keyword in JavaScript. 
Using class would cause conflicts with JavaScript syntax.
react.explanation:
To avoid conflicts with JavaScript syntax, React uses className for specifying CSS classes on elements. 
This allows developers to apply CSS classes to React components without running into conflicts or JavaScript errors.

react.text: What are inline conditional expressions?
react.answer: In JSX, it is possible to include JavaScript expression within curly braces and use it with ternary operators to conditionally render elements
react.explanation: JavaScript has a compact syntax for writing a conditionally render expression ‚Äî the conditional (ternary) operator: {`isSomething` ? ... : ...}

react.text: How do you conditionally render a component in React?
react.answer: All of the above
react.explanation:
In React, is possible to control branching logic with JavaScript. 
If in the component there is a necessity to display different things depending on different conditions - elements could be rendered with conditions. 
Conditionally render JSX uses JavaScript syntax like if statements, logical && operator, and ternary operators.

react.text: Can a nested child component access the state of its sibling component?
react.answer: No, state should be lifted up to a common ancestor & pass it down as props to both siblings
react.explanation:
In React, components can only pass data down to their children through props. 
If a nested child component needs to access the state of its sibling component, the state should be lifted up to a common ancestor and passed down as props to both siblings. 
This ensures that the state is shared between the sibling components and that they stay in sync with each other.

react.text: What are the differences between React and React Native?
react.answer: React Native allows to create native apps, while React builds web user interfaces.
react.explanation:
React is a JavaScript library used for building web user interfaces, while React Native is a framework for developing native mobile applications. 
React renders components to the web browser using virtual DOM, while React Native renders components directly to native UI elements 
for iOS and Android platforms, resulting in a more native-like experience.

react.text: What is the purpose of useContect hook in React?

options.text: Manage state in a functional component
Handle side effects in functional component
Share data between components without props
Update UI before a background operation üèÅ

react.answer: Share data between components without passing props through every level of the component tree
react.explanation:
useContext is a React Hook that provides a way to pass data through the component tree without having to pass props down manually at every level. 
This can be useful for sharing global data, such as themes, user authentication, or language preferences, across multiple components in an application.

react.text: What is the purpose of lazy loading in React?
react.answer: To defer loading component‚Äôs code until it is rendered for the first time.
react.explanation: lazy returns a React component that can be render in your tree. While the code for the lazy component is still loading, attempting to render it will suspend. Use <Suspense> to display a loading indicator while it‚Äôs loading.

react.text: How to optimize the performance of React applications?
react.answer:
Performance optimization techniques for React Applications: 
1) Memoization (useMemo and useCallback). 
2) Code splitting. 
3) Lazy loading. 
4) Pure Components. 
5)Webpack optimizations
react.explanation:
1) Memoization (useMemo and useCallback)- caching the results of expensive functions or computations based on their inputs.
By avoiding redundant calculations, memoization can significantly improve performance 
2) Code-splitting: React applications can be split into smaller code bundles based on routing or functionality. 
This allows the browser to load only the necessary code for the initial render, improving initial load times. 
3)Lazy Loading: this strategy involves loading components only when they are needed. 
This can be particularly beneficial for components that are not immediately visible on the page or are used less frequently. 
React‚Äôs built-in lazy and Suspense features can be used for lazy loading components. 
4)Pure Components: React is designed around this concept. 
React assumes that every component is a pure function. 
5)Webpack optimizations: Webpack is a popular module bundler used in React development. 
It offers various optimization techniques like code minification, tree-shaking, and code splitting to reduce the size of the final bundle and improve loading times.

react.text: What do these three dots (...) in React do?
react.answer: The three dots (...) in React are called the spread operator and can be used to make copies of objects or arrays.
react.explanation:
Spread operator helps to make copies of objects or arrays. 
With objects, it lets to create a new object by copying properties from an existing object and adding or changing specific ones. 
For arrays, it allows to create a new array by combining elements from different arrays. 
The spread operator is handy for manipulating data in React and simplifies tasks like updating component state or merging objects with new properties.

react.text: Does React re-render all components and sub components every time setState is called?
react.answer: No. It only re-renders the components that are affected by the state change
react.explanation:
No. React does not re-render all components and subcomponents every time setState is called. 
It only re-renders the components that are affected by the state change, optimizing performance by avoiding unnecessary updates.

react.text: What is the purpose of the useRef hook in React?

options.text: Manage state in a functional component
Handle side effects in functional component
Update UI before a background operation üèÅ

react.answer: To store information between re-renders
react.explanation:
useRef is a React Hook that allows you to store information between re-renders of a component. 
It is useful for accessing DOM elements, managing focus, and storing mutable values that do not trigger re-renders. 
That is the main difference between useRef and useState: nuseRef does not trigger re-renders when its value changes. 
This means refs are perfect for storing information that doesn‚Äôt affect the visual output of your component. 
For example, if there is a need to store an interval ID and retrieve it later, it can be stored in a ref.

react.text: In which Hook information is local to each copy of the component (unlike the variables outside, which are shared)?
react.answer: useRef
react.explanation:
useRef is a Hook that allows to store mutable values that persist for the entire lifetime of the component. 
It is useful for accessing DOM elements, managing focus, and storing mutable values that do not trigger re-renders. 
Unlike variables declared outside of a component, the values stored in a ref are local to each copy of the component.

react.text: What is the difference between useContext and useState?
react.answer: useState hook allows components to maintain and update their internal state, while the useContext hook facilitates the consumption of context values without excessive nesting.
react.explanation:
useState is a Hook that allows components to maintain and update their internal state. 
useContext is a Hook that facilitates the consumption of context values without excessive nesting. 
useState is used to manage local component state, while useContext is used to access global state that is shared across multiple components.

react.text: What is the main difference between `string refs` and `callback refs` in React.
react.answer: The main difference is that string refs rely on a string identifier, while callback refs use a function to capture the reference.
react.explanation:
useRef helps to store information between re-renders. 
Callback refs are more flexible and allow for better control and manipulation of the reference, making them the preferred method in React 
whereas using string refs approach is considered legacy and is not recommended in newer versions of React. 
Callback refs are particularly useful to access properties or methods that are not directly available through props. 
They give an ability to interact with the underlying DOM elements or component instances directly. 
For example, callback refs can be used to focus an input element programmatically. 
This is especially useful when there is a need to trigger the focus behavior from a button click or other events.

javascript.text: What is Virtual DOM and how it is differ from Real Dom?
javascript.answer:
Virtual DOM is not an actual DOM, but a representation of actual DOM which is kept in memory (Virtual DOM = lightweight copy of the actual DOM, maintained by React). 
It is extremely faster and efficient compare to the browser DOM, as updating a virtual DOM does not require heavy web browser processing like painting and recalibrating the space.
javascript.explanation:
Virtual DOM is nothing but a Javascript (JSON) object that is a representation of the browser DOM. 
It is extremely faster and efficient compare to the browser DOM, as updating a virtual DOM does not require heavy web browser processing like painting and recalibrating the space. 
It involves updating the JavaScript object directly. 
It can produce 20000 virtual dom nodes in a second and created completely from scratch on every setState and dispatch. 
Every time a React component updates, React builds a new tree in memory. 
Creating JavaScript objects in memory on every update is much faster than updating the actual DOM since DOM operations are expensive to perform.

javascript.text: What is the difference between ‚Äô‚Äô==‚Äô‚Äô and ‚Äô‚Äô===‚Äô‚Äô operators in JavaScript?
javascript.answer:
‚Äô‚Äô==‚Äô‚Äô is an equality operator that compares two values for equality after converting them to a common type. 
‚Äù===‚Äô‚Äô is a strict equality operator that compares two values for equality without converting their types. 
For example, ‚Äù1‚Äù == 1 is true, but ‚Äù1‚Äù === 1 is false.
javascript.explanation:
‚Äô‚Äô==‚Äô‚Äô is an equality operator that compares two values for equality after converting them to a common type. 
‚Äù===‚Äô‚Äô is a strict equality operator that compares two values for equality without converting their types. 
For example, ‚Äù1‚Äù == 1 is true, but ‚Äù1‚Äù === 1 is false.

javascript.text: What is the difference between ‚Äùnull‚Äù and ‚Äùundefined‚Äù in JavaScript?
javascript.answer:
‚Äùnull‚Äù represents the absence of a value. 
‚Äùundefined‚Äù is a variable that has been declared but has not been assigned a value.
javascript.explanation:
‚Äùnull‚Äù is an explicit value that represents the absence of a value. 
‚Äùundefined‚Äù is a variable that has been declared but has not been assigned a value. 
In JavaScript, ‚Äùnull‚Äù is a value that represents the intentional absence of any object value, while ‚Äùundefined‚Äù is a type that represents an uninitialized or undeclared value.

javascript.text: What is the difference between HTML and XML
javascript.answer:
XML = eXtensible Markup Language, HTML = HyperText Markup Language, 
XML is more flexible and extensible than HTML, as it allows users to define their own tags and attributes.
javascript.explanation:
XML = eXtensible Markup Language, is a markup language that defines a set of rules for encoding documents in a format that is both human-readable and machine-readable. 
HTML = HyperText Markup Language, is the standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser. 
XML is more flexible and extensible than HTML, as it allows users to define their own tags and attributes. 
HTML is more focused on the presentation of content, while XML is more focused on the structure and organization of data.

javascript.text: Where is the correct place to insert a JavaScript?

options.text: Both the <head> section and the <body> section are correct

javascript.answer: Both the <head> section and the <body> section are correct
javascript.explanation:
Placing JavaScript in the <head> section is suitable for scripts that need to be loaded before the content of the page. 
Common use cases include defining variables, initializing settings, or loading libraries required by the entire page. 
However, keep in mind that including heavy JavaScript files here may delay the rendering of page content. 
Placing JavaScript just before the closing </body> tag is a common practice as it ensures that the page content loads before the script executes. 
This approach enhances the perceived page load time and improves user experience.

javascript.text: What is the purpose of the array slice method?
javascript.answer: The slice() method returns the selected elements in an array as a new array object
javascript.explanation:
The slice() method returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array into a new array object selected from start to end (end not included) 
where start and end represent the index of items in that array: slice(start, end). 
The original array will not be modified.

javascript.text: How do you call a function named ‚ÄùmyFunction‚Äù?
javascript.answer: myFunction()
javascript.explanation:
To call a function named ‚ÄùmyFunction‚Äù, you simply write the function name followed by parentheses: myFunction(). 
This syntax executes the function and runs the code inside it.

javascript.text: How do you convert a string to a number in JavaScript?
javascript.answer: You can convert a string to a number in JavaScript using the parseInt() or parseFloat() functions, or just use the Number() constructor.
javascript.explanation:
The parseInt() function parses a string argument and returns an integer of the specified radix. 
ParseInt only returns whole numbers - decimal part is truncated, whitespace or leading zeros are ignored. 
The parseFloat() function parses a string argument and returns a floating point number. 
JavaScript does not have the distinction of ‚Äùfloating point numbers‚Äù and ‚Äùintegers‚Äù on the language level: parseInt() and parseFloat() only differ in their parsing behavior, but it is not necessary that they will return different values. 
For example: 
const str = ‚Äù42‚Äù; 
const num1 = parseInt(str); // 42 
const num2 = parseFloat(str); // 42 
const num3 = Number(str); // 42

javascript.text: How does a while loop start?
javascript.answer: while (i <= 10)
javascript.explanation:
A while loop starts with the keyword ‚Äùwhile‚Äù, followed by a condition in parentheses. 
The loop will continue to run as long as the condition evaluates to true. 
In this case, the loop will run as long as the variable ‚Äùi‚Äù is less than or equal to 10.

javascript.text: How do you round the number 7.25, to the nearest integer?
javascript.answer: To the nearest integer the floating number is rounded by using the Math.round() method.
javascript.explanation:
The Math.round() method rounds a number to the nearest integer. 
If the fractional portion of the argument is greater than 0.5, the argument is rounded to the integer with the next higher absolute value. 
If it is less than 0.5, the argument is rounded to the integer with the lower absolute value. 
If the fractional portion is exactly 0.5, the argument is rounded to the next integer in the direction of +‚àû. 
**This differs from many languages‚Äù round() functions, which often round half-increments away from zero, giving a different result in the case of negative numbers with a fractional part of exactly 0.5.**

javascript.text: What is the correct JavaScript syntax for opening a new window called ‚ÄùmyWindow‚Äù?
javascript.answer: myWindow = window.open(‚Äùurl‚Äù);
javascript.explanation:
The Window interface represents a window containing a DOM document; the document property points to the DOM document loaded in that window. 
To open a new window in JavaScript, the window.open() method should be used. 
This method creates a new browser window or a new tab, depending on the browser settings. 
Syntax: open(url, target, windowFeatures), url - link 
target - string, without whitespace, specifying the name of the browsing context the resource is being loaded into. 
windowFeatures - parameters, like width, height, left, top, popup window etc. 
For example: myWindow = window.open(‚Äù‚Äùhttps://www.example.com‚Äù‚Äù, ‚Äù‚ÄùmozillaWindow‚Äù‚Äù, ‚Äù‚Äùwidth=320,height=320‚Äù‚Äù)

javascript.text: How do you find the number with the highest value of x and y?
javascript.answer: The Math.max() static method returns the largest of the numbers given as input parameters,
javascript.explanation:
The Math.max() function returns the largest of the given numbers. 
It can be used to find the highest value among a set of numbers. 
Returns NaN if any of the parameters is or is converted into NaN. 
Returns -Infinity if no parameters are provided. 
For example: Math.max(1, 3, 2) - return 3

javascript.text: Name all JavaScript data types
javascript.answer:
1) Number 
2) BigInt 
3) String 
4) Boolean 
5) Symbol 
6) undefined 
7) null 
8) Object
javascript.explanation:
The latest ECMAScript standard defines eight data types: 
Seven data types that are primitives: Boolean, null, undefined, Number, BigInt, String, Symbol. 
The eighth data type - Object is a compound type, which helps to store various keyed collections and more complex entities. 
All types except Object define immutable values represented directly at the lowest level of the language. We refer to values of these types as primitive values. 
All primitive types, except null, can be tested by the typeof operator. typeof null returns ‚Äùobject‚Äù, so one has to use === null to test for null. 
JavaScript is a dynamic language with dynamic types: variables in JavaScript are not directly associated with any particular value type, 
and any variable can be assigned (and re-assigned) values of all types. 
1)Number - storing positive floating-point numbers between -Infinity and +Infinity. 
*NaN (‚ÄùNot a Number‚Äù) is a special kind of number value that‚Äùs typically encountered when the result of an arithmetic operation cannot be expressed as a number. 
It is also the only value in JavaScript that is not equal to itself. 
2) BigInt - helps safely store and operate on large integers even beyond the safe integer limit for Numbers. 
3) String - storing sequences of characters. 
4) Boolean - storing true or false. 
5) Symbol - storing unique identifiers. 
6) undefined - in case when a variable has been declared, but a value has yet not been assigned. 
7) null value represents the intentional absence of any object value. 
null is not an identifier for a property of the global object, like undefined can be. Instead, null expresses a lack of identification, indicating that a variable points to no object. 
In practice, the difference between ‚Äùnull‚Äù & ‚Äùundefined‚Äù is minor, since undefined should not be redefined or shadowed. 
8) Object - storing collections of data and more complex entities.

javascript.text: What is the purpose of the array splice method?
javascript.answer: The splice() method allows to modify an array by adding, removing, or replacing elements.
javascript.explanation:
The splice() method takes max 3 parameters: the index at which to start making changes to the array, the number of elements to remove, element to add to the array. 
The splice() method is a mutating method. It may change the content of this.

javascript.text: What is the difference between slice and splice?
javascript.answer:
1) Slice() method is immutable || splice() method is mutable. 
2)Slice() method used to pick the elements from array || splice() method is used to add or remove elements from array. 
3)Slice() method returns a copy of portion of an array || splice() method returns the removed items.
javascript.explanation:
1) Slice() method is immutable (does not modify the original array), while splice() method is mutable (modifies the original array). 
2)Slice() method returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array into a new array object selected from start to end, 
while splice() method instances changes the contents of an array by removing or replacing existing elements and/or adding new elements. 
3)Slice() method returns a new array containing the extracted elements, while splice() method returns the removed items as an array.

javascript.text: What is the difference between ‚Äùlet‚Äù and ‚Äùvar‚Äù in JavaScript?
javascript.answer:
1)‚Äùlet‚Äù is block-scoped, while ‚Äùvar‚Äù is function-scoped or global-scoped. 
2)‚Äúvar‚Äù variables can be declared below their use, while ‚Äùlet‚Äù - should be declared before assignment. 
3)‚Äùvar‚Äù tolerates redeclarations, while ‚Äùlet‚Äù does not. 
4)‚Äùlet‚Äù is a modern variable declaration, while ‚Äùvar‚Äù is an older one.
javascript.explanation:
‚Äùvar‚Äù is generally not used in modern scripts, but still lurks in the old ones. 
The main difference is that variables, declared with var, are either function-scoped or global-scoped. 
They are visible through blocks = give an access to variables that are defined inside loops or if statements, because those variables are global. 
If var is in a code block that is inside a function, then var becomes a function-level variable, and outside this function variable`s value would be undefined. 
‚Äùlet‚Äù is block-scoped, meaning that it is only available within the block it is defined in. 
‚Äùlet‚Äù is a modern variable declaration that is preferred over ‚Äùvar‚Äù in most cases. 
‚Äùlet‚Äù does not tolerate redeclarations, while ‚Äùvar‚Äù does. 
‚Äùlet‚Äù variables must be declared before they are used, while ‚Äùvar‚Äù variables can be declared below their use.

javascript.text: What is the correct JavaScript syntax for writing ‚ÄùHello World‚Äù?
javascript.answer: document.write(‚ÄùHello World‚Äù)
javascript.explanation:
The document.write() method writes a string of text to a document stream opened by document.open(). 
Because document.write() writes to the document stream, calling document.write() on a closed (loaded) document automatically calls document.open(), which will clear the document. 
! Use of the document.write() method is strongly discouraged: this method has very idiosyncratic behavior. 
In some cases this method is dependent on network latency, which can lead to failures that are very hard to debug. 
In other cases, the call can clear the current page first, as if document.open() had been called. 
In yet more cases, the method is simply ignored, or throws an exception.

javascript.text: What are arrow functions?
javascript.answer:
Arrow functions are a shorthand syntax for writing function expressions in JavaScript. 
They use the => syntax to separate the function parameters from the function body and have a concise syntax that makes them ideal for writing short, one-liner functions.
javascript.explanation:
An arrow function expression is a compact alternative to a traditional function expression, with some semantic differences and deliberate limitations in usage: 
1)Arrow functions don‚Äùt have their own bindings to this, arguments, or super, and should not be used as methods. 
2)They cannot be used as constructors. Calling them with new throws a TypeError. 
Arrow functions are always unnamed. If the arrow function needs to call itself, it is better to use a named function expression instead.

javascript.text: What will the following code return: typeof ‚ÄùHello‚Äù?
javascript.answer: string
javascript.explanation:
The typeof operator returns a string indicating the type of the unevaluated operand. 
Depending on the context typeof operator could return: 
1)‚Äùundefined‚Äù. 
2)‚Äùboolean‚Äù. 
3)‚Äùsymbol‚Äù. 
4)‚Äùnumber‚Äù. 
5)‚Äùbigint‚Äù. 
6)‚Äùstring‚Äù. 
7)‚Äùfunction‚Äù. 
8)‚Äùobject‚Äù (for type ‚Äùnull‚Äù or any other object).

javascript.text: What is the first class function?
javascript.answer: First-class function is a function, that acts like any other variable in that language.

javascript.text: Which method is used to create a new array with all elements that pass a test implemented by the provided function?
javascript.answer: filter()
javascript.explanation:
The filter() method creates a shallow copy of a portion of a given array, filtered down to just the elements from the given array that pass the test implemented by the provided function. 
It does not change the original array.

javascript.text: What is a higher order function?
javascript.answer: A higher-order function is a function that takes one or more functions as arguments and/or returns a function as its result.

javascript.text: What does the yield keyword do in a generator function?

options.text: Pauses the function execution and returns a value

javascript.answer: Pauses the function execution and returns a value
javascript.explanation:
The yield operator is used to pause and resume a generator function (created by calling: ‚Äùfunction*‚Äô‚Äô). 
A generator function is a special type of function that can be paused and resumed. 
When a generator function is called, it returns an iterator object but does not execute its body immediately. 
When the iterator‚Äôs next() method is called, the generator function‚Äôs body is executed until the first yield expression, which specifies the value to be returned by the iterator. 
When the iterator‚Äôs next() method is called again, the generator function resumes execution from the point where it was paused until the next yield expression or return statement is encountered. 
The yield keyword is used to pause the function execution and return a value. 
It can be used to produce a sequence of values, one at a time, from a function.

javascript.text: What is hoisting?
javascript.answer: JavaScript Hoisting refers to the process whereby the interpreter appears to move the declaration of functions, variables, classes, or imports to the top of their scope, prior to execution of the code.
javascript.explanation:
Hoisting is a behavior in JavaScript where variable and function declarations are moved to the top of their respective scopes during compilation or interpretation, before the code is actually executed. 
This means that you can use a variable or function before it has been declared, but only if it is declared using the var or function keywords. 
However, only the declarations themselves are hoisted, not their values or assignments. 
Hoisting is not a term normatively defined in the ECMAScript specification. 
The spec does define a group of declarations as ‚ÄùHoistableDeclaration‚Äù, but this only includes ‚Äùfunction‚Äù, ‚Äùfunction*‚Äô‚Äô, ‚Äùasync function‚Äù, and ‚Äùasync function* declarations‚Äù. 
Hoisting is often considered a feature of var declarations as well, although in a different way. 
In colloquial terms, any of the following behaviors may be regarded as hoisting: 
1.)Being able to use a variable‚Äùs value in its scope before the line it is declared. (‚ÄùValue hoisting‚Äù); 
2.)Being able to reference a variable in its scope before the line it is declared, without throwing a ReferenceError, but the value is always undefined. (‚ÄùDeclaration hoisting‚Äù); 
3.)The declaration of the variable causes behavior changes in its scope before the line in which it is declared; 
4.)The side effects of a declaration are produced before evaluating the rest of the code that contains it.

javascript.text: Which method is used to execute a function after a specified number of milliseconds?
javascript.answer: setTimeout()

javascript.text: What is callback in JavaScript?
javascript.answer: A callback is a function that is passed as an argument to another function and is intended to be called when the first function has completed its task.
javascript.explanation:
There are two ways in which the callback may be called: synchronous and asynchronous. 
Synchronous callbacks are called immediately after the invocation of the outer function, with no intervening asynchronous tasks, while asynchronous callbacks are called at some point later, after an asynchronous operation has completed. 
Examples of synchronous callbacks include the callbacks passed to Array.prototype.map(), Array.prototype.forEach(), etc. 
Examples of asynchronous callbacks include the callbacks passed to setTimeout() and Promise.prototype.then().

javascript.text: What is an Early return pattern?
javascript.answer: The Early return pattern is a programming pattern (not specific only to Javascript), where a function or method returns as soon as a condition is met, rather than executing the rest of the function.
javascript.explanation:
The Early Return pattern is a coding technique where a function or method is stopped as soon as a specific condition is met and evaluates to true. 
Instead of proceeding with the rest of the function‚Äùs logic, the method immediately returns a value or performs an action based on the condition‚Äùs outcome. 
In simple terms, everything that we wouldn‚Äùt want to happen in our function we would write at the top, and everything that we want to happen - we would write at the bottom.

javascript.text: What is the output of ‚Äùconsole.log(typeof (() => {}))‚Äô‚Äô?
javascript.answer: function
javascript.explanation:
The typeof operator returns a string indicating the type of the unevaluated operand. 
In this case, typeof (() => {}) returns ‚Äùfunction‚Äù.

javascript.text: What is a cookie in JavaScript?
javascript.answer: A cookie is a small piece of data that is commonly used to remember user preferences and login information, and to track user activity on a website.
javascript.explanation:
A cookie is a small piece of data a server sends to a user‚Äùs web browser. 
The browser may store cookies, create new cookies, modify existing ones, and send them back to the same server with later requests. 
Cookies enable web applications to store limited amounts of data and remember state information; by default the HTTP protocol is stateless. 
Typically, the server will use the contents of HTTP cookies to determine whether different requests come from the same browser/user and then issue a personalized or generic response as appropriate. 
Cookies are mainly used for three purposes: 
1)Session management: Logins, shopping carts, game scores, or anything else the server should remember. 
2)Personalization: User preferences such as display language and UI themes. 
3)Tracking: Recording and analyzing user behavior.

javascript.text: What does the Object.is() method do?

options.text: Checks if two values are equal with type coercion
Checks if two values are equal without type coercion, considering NaN and signed zeros
Checks if two values are strictly equal
Checks if two objects have the same properties

javascript.answer: Checks if two values are equal without type coercion, considering NaN and signed zeros

javascript.text: What is AJAX?
javascript.answer: AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML) is a technique to update the relevant parts of the page without requiring a full page load
javascript.explanation:
Asynchronous JavaScript and XML (Ajax, or AJAX) is a web development technique in which a web app fetches content from the server by making asynchronous HTTP requests, and uses the new content to update the relevant parts of the page without requiring a full page load. 
This can make the page more responsive, because only the parts that need to be updated are requested. 
Ajax can be used to create single-page apps, in which the entire web app consists of a single document, which uses Ajax to update its content as needed. 
Initially Ajax was implemented using the XMLHttpRequest interface, but the fetch() API is more suitable for modern web applications: it is more powerful, more flexible, and integrates better with fundamental web app technologies such as service workers. 
Modern web frameworks also provide abstractions for Ajax.
